label: grammatical marker
definition: A grammatical marker (or simply marker) is a bound form occurring on a single host root class or in second clause position that expresses some grammatical meaning related to its host or to the clause.

label: bound form
definition: A bound form is a form that cannot occur on its own as a complete utterance.

label: host
definition: A host is an expression with respect to which a bound form (a clitic or an affix) is positioned.

label: second (clause) position
definition: The second position of a clause is the position after the initial nominal, adverbial or verb form.

label: grammatical meaning
definition: A grammatical meaning is a meaning that need not be expressed overtly in some languages but can be left for inference.

label: noun
definition: A noun is a simplex item that denotes a thing or a person, and by extension a simplex item that denotes something else but behaves like a noun in the strict sense with respect to grammatical coding and syntactic patterns. Complex items that behave like nouns can also be considered nouns.

label: numeral classifier system
definition: A numeral classifier system is a system of nomifiers which occurs on numerals and possibly on other adnominal modifiers but not on predicates.
quotation: Gil (2005): "in many ... languages, nouns in construction with numerals may occur with an additional grammatical element even when such nouns are of high countability... Such elements are typically referred to as sortal numeral classifiers. This term makes reference to one of the most salient functions of such forms, which is to divide the inventory of count nouns into semantic classes, each of which is associated with a different classifier."

label: possessive classifier system
definition: A possessive classifier system is a system of genifiers which occur on adpossessive modifiers but not anywhere else.

label: gender system
definition: A gender system (= a system of gender markers) is a system of nomifiers which includes no more than 20 nomifiers and whose nomifiers are not restricted to occurring on numeral modifiers.

label: TAM marker
definition: marker of tense, aspect or mood

label: TAM
definition: tense, aspect and/or mood

label: nomifier system
definition: A nomifier system is a paradigm of grammatical markers which occur on adnominal modifiers, person indexes or anaphoric pronouns, and each of which expresses (i.e. normally reflects, but sometimes contributes) a broad property other than person and number of the controlling noun (i.e. for adnominal modifiers: the modificatum, for person indexes: an argument, for anaphoric pronouns: the antecedent).

label: predicate
definition: [The predicate of a simple clause may be a verb form, a nominal, an adjective, or a locational expression.]

label: negator
definition: A negator is a form that expresses negation and does not simultaneously express a root meaning (event, thing, property)
comments: A fully equivalent term is "negative marker", but "negator" is preferred here, because a negator is not a grammatical marker in the sense that is has grammatical meaning as defined here

label: affirmative clause
definition: a clause lacking a negative marker with scope over the clause

label: scope
definition: PRIMITIVE

label: definite or specific article
definition: A definite or specific article is an article that is used on nominals that are definite or specific, can be used in associative contexts, and has no spatial deictic meaning.

label: indefinite article
definition: An indefinite article is an article that very frequently accompanies indefinite nouns and that never accompanies definite nouns.
comments:
(From my Github comment: 
The problem here may be with deciding whether nominals "commonly" have an indefinite article in this language. If "there are examples of indefinite nominals without an article", this does not mean that there can be no indefinite article – unless one is as strict as the wiki comments say (" In this question we need explicit support that indefinite NPs cannot occur without an indefinite/non-specific article." – but this is too strict. I think there are very few if any languages where indefinite articles MUST occur on ALL indefinite nominals. I think it's more reasonable to define "commonly have an indefinite article" as "clearly more often than one would use the numeral 'one' in a language like English that distinguished between 'one' and indefinite articles".)

label: independent personal pronoun
definition: An independent personal pronoun is a personal pronoun that is a free form.
quotation: Siewierska (2004: 16): "The basic division of person markers in regard to morphophonological form is that between independent and dependent person markers. Other terms used for the independent forms are free, full, self/standing, cardinal, focal, strong, long and disjunctive. ... Typically what is meant by an independent/free/full, etc. person form is a person marker which constitutes a separate word and may take primary word stress, such as the English I, me, you, she, they.
comments: An alternative term that is often used is "free personal pronoun". Since personal pronouns in English, German and Russian are always free, the modifier "independent" is very often omitted. The definition here is not in terms of "separate word" (as in Siewierska 2004: 16), but in terms of "free form".
GOLD comment: GOLD does not distinguish between independent personal pronouns and bound person forms. Thus, GOLD's "Personal Pronoun" does not provide a good match, but it is the best match.

label: plural marker
definition: A plural marker is a grammatical marker occurring on a noun or nominal that indicates that the referent set contains more than one item.

label: accusative flag
definition: An accusative flag is a flag that marks a nominal as P-argument (in a transitive clause).
comments:
(1) This function need not be the only function; such flags commonly also express temporal extension (e.g. German eine-n Tag [one-ACC day] ‘for one day’), or the R-argument in a ditransitive clause.

(2) In many languages, only some of the P-arguments are marked by an accusative flag, in particular those with relatively high prominence (“differential object marking”).
GOLD comment: GOLD only takes accusative "case" into account, neglecting accusative "adpositions".

label: flag
definition: A flag is a marker that occurs on a nominal and gives information about its semantic role or syntactic role.
comments: The term "flag" is a recent innovation in typology to refer to case forms and adpositions jointly. In the past, it was often necessary to refer to "case-marking and adpositional marking", but "flagging" is much more convenient.

label: transitive clause
definition: A transitive clause is a clause which contains two arguments that are coded in the same way as the arguments of the verbs 'kill' and/or 'break'.

label: P-argument
definition: A P-argument is the patient argument of a physical-effect verb ('kill', 'break').

label: article
definition: An article is a short form that often accompanies a noun and that indicates(in)definiteness or (non)specificity or a very closely related notion.

label: (in)definite nominal
definition: A nominal is (in)definite if its referent can(not) be uniquely determined within a contextually pragmatic set by the hearer.

label: specific nominal
definition: A nominal is specific if it has a referent in the speaker's reality space (one of their mental spaces).
comments: maybe this should be "specific referential expression"

label: demonstrative
definition: "A demonstrative is a form that establishes reference by deixis and that can be accompanied by a pointing gesture."

label: complementizer
definition: A complementizer is a marker that indicates that the clause on which it occurs is a complement clause.

label: clusivity
definition: the distinction between a group including speaker and hearer (inclusive) and a group including the speaker but excluding the hearer (exclusive)

label: complement clause
definition: a clause that is an argument of a verb

label: adnominal modifier
definition: (An adnominal modifier is a modifier that occurs adnominally.)
comments: An older alternative term is "attribute", and "attributive" is a synonym of "adnominal" that is still very widely used.

label: affix
definition: An affix is a bound form that occurs adjacent to roots of only one root-class and is not interruptible by free forms from it.

label: root
definition: A root is a form that does not contain other forms and that denotes an event, a thing or a property.
comments: Other definitions of root make reference to word, e.g. "The unanalyzable core of a word", but since word cannot be easily defined, it is better to define root in terms of the most important meanings. Including other meanings is not necessary, because these never behave in a special way.

label: form
definition: A form in spoken language is a conventional pairing of a sound shape and a semiotic function (i.e. a meaning in its broadest sense).

label: root-class
definition: A root-class is one of the following three classes: action roots, thing roots, and property roots.

label: free form
definition: A free form is a form that can occur on its own as a well-formed utterance.

label: person index
definition: A person index is a bound person form.

label: person form
definition: A person form is a form that denotes 1st, 2nd or 3rd person, i.e. the speech role of the speaker, the speech role of the hearer, or a referent that is neither speaker nor hearer.

label: possessive person index
definition: A possessive person index is a person index that denotes an adpossessor (i.e. an adnominal possessor).

label: adpossessor
definition: An adpossessor (or adnominal possessor) is an adnominal modifier that denotes a possessive relationship.

label: possessive relationship
definition: A possessive relationship is a relationship of kinship, of part-whole, or of ownership.
comments: In all languages, the forms for possessive relationships are also used for other, loosely associative relationships, such as 'my path (on which I'm walking)', 'my chair (on which I'm sitting)', 'my school (which I attend)'. These are not part of the definition because such meanings are never expressed in a special way.

label: affixal possessive person index
definition: An affixal possessive person index is a possessive person index that is an affix, i.e. only occurs on the noun, not on adnominal modifiers.

label: possidend noun
definition: A possidend noun is a noun that obligatorily carries a possessive person index.

label: possessive classifier
definition: A possessive classifier is a genifier that is part of a possessive classifier system.

label: neutral order
definition: A neutral order of elements is one that occurs in constructions that do not involve special discourse highlighting such as focusing or topicalization.

label: property word
definition: A property word is a form containing at least one root that denotes a property such as 'old', 'big', 'good', 'red'.

label: definite(ness)
definition: A definite nominal is a nominal whose referent can be uniquely identified by the hearer, as in anaphoric situations, to refer back to something mentioned in the preceding discourse (e.g. I bought a new bicycle... My husband likes the bicycle), or in associative contexts, to refer to something that is not mentioned in the preceding discourse but that is identifiable because of an associative relationship (e.g. I bought a new bicycle. The saddle is very comfortable).

label: subordinate clause
definition: A subordinate clause is a clause that is a relative clause, a complement clause, or an adverbial clause.

label: subordinator
definition: A subordinator is a grammatical marker that
comments: Note that traditionally, subordinators are called "subordinating conjunctions", but it is very hard (and actually not necessary) to define a concept "conjunction" that comprises both coordinators and subordinators, so here this traditional concept is not used.

label: particle
definition: A particle is a short form that is not an affix, not a root, not a pronoun, not a flag, not a coordinator, not a subordinator, and not an auxiliary verb.

label: personal pronoun
definition: A personal pronoun is a person form that cannot cooccur with a conominal.
comments: When a person form can cooccur with a conominal, it is called "cross-index", and when it must cooccur with it, it is called "gramm-index". When a personal pronoun is a bound person form (i.e. a person index), it can be called "pro-index".
GOLD comment: GOLD does not distinguish between independent personal pronouns and bound person forms.

label: argument coding
definition: Argument coding includes person indexing on the verb, flagging on the argument nominal, and fixed word order.

label: conominal
definition: A conominal is a nominal that can cooccur in the same clause with a person index and that is coreferential with it.
comments: Note that when a person index can cooccur with a conominal, it is a cross-index or a gramm-index. Conominals are also often referred to as "appositional NPs".

label: interrogative pronoun
definition: An interrogative pronoun is a form that occurs in a content question and that occupies the position of the open parameter at issue.
comments:
(LINGTYP Oct 2017)

This definition would comprise forms such as Italian "cosa" (which means 'what?' or 'thing'), as well as French "que" (which is a bound form, in that it cannot occur by itself). Perhaps these are not "genuine" interrogative pronouns, in the sense that they are free forms (like Latin "quid?"), or in the sense that they only occur in an interrogative context (again like Latin "quid?"). But since even the forms of well-known languages may occur in non-interrogative contexts (e.g. most English wh-pronouns, used in relative clauses), it does not seem reasonable to define "interrogative pronoun" in a narrow sense.

I do share the feeling that Abkhaz and Abaza are unusual in some way, but I'm not sure how best to express this with clear comparative concepts. These elements may have been described as part of "verbal morphology", but this is more a claim about the orthography than about any clear property of the language.

label: person
definition: Person is a dimension of grammatical meaning which has three values, two of which are speech roles: the speaker (1st person) and the hearer (2nd person), plus other referents that are neither speaker nor hearer (and do not include them) (3rd person).

label: A-argument
definition: An A-argument is the agent argument of a physical-effect verb ('kill', 'break').

label: applicative marker
definition: An applicative marker is a grammatical marker occurring on a verb that changes the verb's valency in such a way that an argument with a specific role gets to be coded like the P-argument in simple transitive clauses.
comments: There are various subtypes of applicative markers, depending on the role which they transform into a P-argument. Thus, for example, an instrumental applicative marker is an applicative marker that transforms a nominal with an instrumental role into a P-argument.

label: instrumental role
definition: A nominal bears an instrumental role if it serves to express the instrument (implement carried in the hand, body part, means of transport, or language) with which an action is carried out by the agent.

label: R-argument
definition: The R-argument of a ditransitive verb is the argument that expresses the recipient or addressee participant or that is coded in the same way as these.

label: ditransitive verb
definition: A ditransitive verb is a verb that expresses transfer – physical transfer of possession, like 'give', or mental transfer of information, like 'tell'.

label: recipient role
definition: A nominal bears a recipient role if it serves to express the recipient of a physical transfer of possession verb ('give', 'lend').

label: addressee role
definition: A nominal bears an addressee role if it serves to express the addressee of a mental transfer of information verb ('tell', 'teach').

label: negation
definition: (no definition – a primitive)

label: standard negator
definition: A standard negator is a negator that occurs in declarative nonsubordinate clauses with a verbal predicate.

label: declarative sentence
definition: (no definition – primitive concept)

label: root suppletion
definition: Root suppletion is a situation where two different root forms have the same meaning and occur in different grammatical contexts in complementary distribution.

label: strong root suppletion
definition: Strong root suppletion is a situation where two root forms that do not share the first two segments have the same meaning and occur in different grammatical contexts in complementary distribution.

label: weak root suppletion
definition: Weak root suppletion is a situation where two root forms that share the first two segments but are not regularly related have the same meaning and occur in different grammatical contexts in complementary distribution.

label: core argument
definition: A core argument is an A-argument, a P-argument, or an S-argument, or another argument that is coded like one of these.

label: S-argument
definition: An S-argument is the single argument of a noncausal change-of-state verb ('die', 'fall').

label: transitivizer
definition: A transitivizer is a grammatical marker that combines with an intransitive verb and indicates that the resulting verb is transitive.

label: transitive verb
definition: A transitive verb is a verb that may occur in a transitive clause.

label: intransitive clause
definition: An intransitive clause is a clause which is not transitive, i.e. which does not contain two arguments that are coded in the same way as the arguments of the verbs 'kill' and/or 'break'.

label: intransitive verb
definition: An intransitive verb is a verb that may occur in an intransitive clause.

label: reflexive pronoun
definition: A reflexive pronoun is a form that is nominal-like in that it can be flagged and that indicates that its referent is coreferential with the subject.

label: reflexive marker
definition: A reflexive marker is a bound form that occurs on verbs and indicates that the subject and an object are coreferential.

label: subject
definition: The subject of a clause is its S-argument when the clause is intransitive and its A-argument when the clause is transitive.

label: object
definition: An object of a clause is its P-argument when the clause is transitive, and its T-argument or its R-argument when the clause is ditransitive.

label: reciprocal marker
definition: A reciprocal marker is a bound form that occurs on verbs and indicates that the subject and an object are in a mutual relationship.

label: dominant order
definition: The dominant order of two (or more) forms is the order that occurs in at least two thirds of the occurrences in texts.

label: animate
definition: A noun or nominal or referent is animate if it denotes a human being or an animal.
